content: The addressbook would be abook.sqlite, or if older, then abook.mab, and possibly history.sqlite and history.mab. You can import them from within Thunderbird by tools>import>import from a file and then follow the prompts.

content:
Hello there We have read the message We try to help.

We assume that you have an existing account for the Thunderbird version. And has a password saved for this

You can use certain options in the program to solve this issue.

We assume that you have an already installed account of the Thunderbird software. Here you choose extra - options - assigned passwords in your menu dropdown options. In your browser/menu you can choose security - passwords - find saved passwords.

The option to choose saved passwords allows you to use the delete all button to clear the cache for security passwords used for this.

The option to choose saved passwords allows you to use the delete all button to clear the security password cache for this purpose when restarting Thunderbird.

Afterwards , hereby you will be asked for a new password.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb

It will only replace your Thunderbird password, not your Thunderbird account password.

Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
I was able to solve the problem:

- I did a text search on "flogs.nl" in the datafiles of Thunderbird on my notebook, especially in the Thunderbird profile folder. I found this text in two files: 

  - prefs.js   - global-messages-db.sqlite

And in "prefs.js" I found this text in a calendar registry:

user_pref("calendar.registry.ab731960-94c8-4760-b717-59c0ac89290a.uri", "http://www.flogs.nl/p/128720.g8hISf8GU3VaOA1Y8usFsw/60");

This correlated with a calender I installed a long time ago for holidays. So I removed this calendar, and the problems was solved!
creator: thirdfloor

content:

content:
Please note gmail have limits on number/size of emails that get imported via imap. Maybe your issue is due to the limit being reached ? Upload with IMAP is 500 MB per day. https://support.google.com/a/answer/1071518?hl=en

Do you have any Anti-Virus etc scanning outgoing emails ? If yes, then the intervening scanning process may be slowing things down. Stop scanning outgoing mail.

You could try increasing the timeout.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor'
  • It opens in new tab - Advanced Preferences
  • In top search type: tcpt
  • look for this line: mailnews.tcptimeout
  • click on the pencil icon to edit
  • Increase the number - (mine is 100 by default) try 500
  • click on the tick icon to save
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
snipping tool is an image making tool. It can save files a many image formats. PNG, JPG and GIF It is those file types that can be associated to an application, not an application. Normally windows will have those file types associated with an image manipulation program like photos or the venerable paint.

What are you trying to achieve really. because I think your process and what you are trying to achieve are not compatible

content:
It appears that the problem started with Microsoft on Wednesday 24 (lots of down detector login failures) and they finally acknowledged something Friday 26 but not obvioulsy displayed on their website.

However their status page on Wednesday 31 still reports Outlook mail working OK. Failures from MS Office suites, Thunderbird, other mail programs, and Apple products included. Their suggested work around is to log into Outlook via a web browser for now.

I have found that repeat pressing of login will get you there, and from then on it seems mostly to hang togtehr and I ignore any follow-up login requests. Not ideal, but....

So when MS decides to do something perhaps some of the pain will subside.
